query: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is caused by small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV), which is classified within the genus __________ of the family Paramyxoviridae.
The tight junction–based structure formed by Sertoli cells that isolates haploid germ cells from the innate immune system is the __________.
Goat pox cannot be reliably differentiated from sheep pox virus (SPPV) infection using serological assays, so definitive diagnosis typically requires __________ techniques.
CircFUT10 modulates bovine adipocyte differentiation by acting as a competing endogenous RNA that sponges the microRNA ________ to inhibit differentiation.

Scrapie, a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy, is defined neuropathologically by the accumulation in the central nervous system of the abnormal prion protein isoform designated __________, which arises from conformational conversion of the cellular prion protein.

Forceful inspiratory efforts during the first respirations can generate intrathoracic pressures as low as __________, creating the airway pressure gradient needed to move air into liquid-filled newborn lungs.

In humans, cationic host defence peptides (CHDP) are primarily classified into two major families—__________ and defensins—whose expression can be upregulated after PAMP recognition by PRRs such as Toll-like receptors (TLR) and NOD receptors (NLRs).
APP reaches the presynaptic zone via fast __________ transport from neuronal somatodendritic and axonal compartments.

In Arabian horses, severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is inherited in a(n) __________ fashion, causing homozygous foals to be fatally immunodeficient while heterozygous carriers remain asymptomatic.

Neospora caninum and Toxoplasma gondii can produce morphologically similar lesions in ovine abortions such that accurate differentiation between them cannot be achieved using routine __________ techniques.

In horses, submaximal exercise significantly decreases hepatic blood flow, leading to the hypothesis that drugs efficiently extracted by the liver may exhibit decreased __________ clearance during such exercise.

Ovine babesiosis is a hemolytic disease in small ruminants transmitted by ixodid ticks, and the most pathogenic implicated species is Babesia __________, which is generally transmitted by ticks in the genus *Rhipicephalus*.

Milk allergenicity can shift because genetic polymorphisms and post-translational modifications (e.g., glycosylation and phosphorylation) alter protein structure and functional properties such as micelle stability, solubility, and __________.

During early sheep embryogenesis, full activation of embryonic transcription occurs at the ________ stage, marking completion of the maternal-to-embryonic transition before compaction-associated polarization at the morula stage.

Gudair® vaccination can markedly reduce clinical ovine Johne’s disease yet still allow prolonged faecal shedding of Mycobacterium avium subspecies __________ in some flocks vaccinated for over a decade, creating a risk of disease resurgence if vaccination is stopped.

In a high-fat diet mouse model, dietary inclusion of goat’s milk produced anti-obesity and insulin-sensitizing effects that were linked to higher energy expenditure and a shift in skeletal muscle toward more __________ fibers, alongside reduced inflammatory markers.
In ovine footrot, *Dichelobacter nodosus* strains are classified as virulent or benign using the amino acid sequence of an extracellular __________.
In treating equine stringhalt, intramuscular botulinum toxin injections into the extensor digitorum lateralis and lateral vastus can reduce hyperflexion/hyperabduction for up to __________ weeks.

In the “bow-and-string” mechanical model of the equine thoracolumbar spine, inadequate tension generated by the abdominal and sublumbar musculature permits the weight of the viscera to ________ the intervertebral joints, producing a more lordotic back contour.
Equine influenza A virus can disseminate beyond direct close contact via a wind-borne aerosol over a maximum distance of __________.

A control program for ovine haemonchosis that avoids the production-trait tradeoffs of crossbreeding and addresses widespread anthelmintic resistance can remain workable by combining targeted selective treatment with selective breeding, culling of highly susceptible animals, and maintaining a good __________ score through provision of a balanced diet.

Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) is primarily managed through dietary strategies and exercise programs intended to improve insulin regulation and reduce obesity, with the most important risk factor for endocrinopathic laminitis being __________.

In small animal periodontal pathology, the initial stage characterized by active inflammation confined to the gingiva and considered reversible with professional dental cleaning and proper home care is termed __________.

In equine practice, when no genetic assay is available, suspected inherited bleeding disorders are typically evaluated by assessing platelet function, von Willebrand factor, and the levels/activities of other __________ proteins.

Vascular occlusion during horseback riding becomes a concern when applied pressure exceeds the mean capillary pressure of $4.7\,\mathrm{kPa}$, and a suggested threshold indicating risk of inducing back pain is a mean saddle pressure greater than __________.

Classical scrapie pathogenesis features conversion of the normal cellular prion protein into a misfolded disease-associated isoform denoted __________, which contains a proteinase K–resistant core termed PrP^res.

In the beam-on-two-supports model of a quadruped’s body stem, ventral sagging of the trunk between the supports produces compression along the __________ margin and tension along the __________ margin.
The segment of the equine thoracolumbar spine identified as the most mobile lies specifically between vertebrae __________ and __________.

In naturally acquired Clostridium difficile–associated disease (CDAD) in older foals and adult horses, intestinal lesions typically show a more aboral distribution, affecting the __________ and sometimes the cecum, while only rarely involving the small intestine.

Thoroughbred breeding has historically selected for speed over distances of ________ to 2 miles, whereas Quarter Horse selection has emphasized speed over shorter distances and a compliant disposition for ranch work.

Complementary and alternative veterinary medicine (CAVM) encompasses preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic practices outside the traditional veterinary curriculum; when these practices are used *instead of* conventional treatments, the approach is classified as __________ medicine.

Alopecia areata is clinically defined by a sudden or insidious onset of well-circumscribed, nonscarring alopecia that is visually __________, distinguishing it from alopecias with overt erythema or scaling.

African horse sickness virus transmission is primarily attributed to Culicoides imicola, but in the cooler upper highlands of South Africa a different vector, __________, has been shown to play an important role.
Despite being long treated as a “dead-end” host for influenza A, the documented spillover of equine-lineage influenza viruses to __________ has directly challenged that characterization.

African horse sickness virus (AHSV) structural proteins form three concentric capsid layers in which the inner capsid is composed of VP7 and VP3 and encloses the replication-complex minor proteins VP1, VP4, and VP6 as well as the genome; the two proteins that instead form the outer capsid are VP2 and __________.

The myostatin gene (MSTN), which encodes Growth Differentiation Factor 8 (GDF8), functions as a negative regulator of muscle growth by decreasing the proliferation rate of equine muscle precursor cells through inhibition of __________ progression.

African swine fever virus (ASFV), the sole member of the family Asfarviridae (genus Asfivirus), is described as a complex, large, icosahedral, multi-enveloped __________ virus whose genome encodes numerous viral enzymes, transcription factors, and immune homologues.

In acute and subacute African swine fever virus (ASFV) infection, severe lymphopenia is often attributed to lymphocyte apoptosis triggered by pro-inflammatory __________ produced by infected macrophages.

Agricultural fairs in North America, which attract nearly __________ million attendees annually and often co-house multi-source pigs for multiple days, create conditions conducive to amplification of influenza A virus and subsequent zoonotic transmission.

Norovirus is a(n) __________-sense single-stranded RNA virus classified within the Caliciviridae family, a fact that underpins its ability to serve as a leading global cause of acute gastroenteritis with an estimated 600 million cases annually.

Classical swine fever virus is characterized as a small, enveloped RNA virus classified within the genus __________, and its three genotypes distinguished by partial sequences do not directly correlate with virulence.

Equine monocytes exhibit exceptionally high sensitivity to *Escherichia coli* LPS, achieving half-maximal release of TNF-α and expression of tissue factor at an $\mathrm{EC}_{50}$ range of __________ $\mathrm{ng/mL}$.

Peracute colitis caused by Clostridioides difficile in horses is frequently complicated by severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and treated with NSAIDs, antimicrobials, anti-LPS therapy, and fluid therapy; however, in horses with renal compromise, the use of polymyxin B is often limited because of its potential __________ effects.

CSFV sub-genotype 1.4 was established after phylogenetic analyses of full-length __________ sequences showed Cuban isolates (previously assigned to 1.2) formed a distinct, highly divergent lineage within genotype 1.

Back pain/stiffness in horses and experimentally induced forelimb or hindlimb lameness can both alter spinal biomechanics and shift the horse’s __________, a change that may predispose to rider back pain/stiffness and abnormal saddle movement such as consistent saddle slip to one side.

Swine are considered “mixing vessels” for influenza A virus reassortment because their respiratory tract expresses both avian- and human-adapted __________ (SA) receptor types, enabling co-infection by IAVs of different origins.
Classical swine fever is caused by classical swine fever virus (CSFV), which belongs to the genus __________ within the family Flaviviridae.

Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) expresses a single long ORF that is translated into a primary polyprotein, which is subsequently cleaved by cellular and viral proteases into 12 mature proteins, including the four structural proteins C, Erns, E1, and __________.

African swine fever virus (ASFV) field strains are genetically grouped into 22 genotypes by sequencing the C-terminus of the __________ protein, a strategy used because discernible ASFV serotypes are lacking.

African swine fever virus (ASFV) transmission can occur in three epidemiologic cycles—sylvatic, tick-pig, and domestic—of which the __________ cycle is characterized by virus spread among domestic pigs and via pig-derived products, without involving the natural reservoirs (warthogs and soft Ornithodoros ticks).

Human-to-swine spillback of A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses was estimated to have occurred at least __________ times globally, creating repeated opportunities for reassortment with endemic swine influenza A lineages, including those carrying the TRIG internal gene cassette.
In chronic classical swine fever, clinical signs are generally milder yet persist for approximately __________ weeks.
Classical swine fever virus (CSFV)–induced interferons (IFNs) drive antiviral immunity by activating the __________ signaling pathway, which governs transcription of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs).
In swine, the SLA (MHC) complex is uniquely split by the centromere such that the class I and class III regions map to 7p1.1 while the class II region maps to __________.

African swine fever virus (ASFV) virion architecture is described as multilayered, consisting of a nucleoprotein core, core shell, inner envelope, viral capsid, and an external envelope that is present specifically when the virus __________ from the host cell.

African swine fever virus (ASFV) exhibits limited or no cross-protection across its many genotypes, a feature that helps explain why vaccines based on simple inactivation, attenuation, or individual recombinant proteins/DNA often yield only __________ protection.
Pigs facilitate the emergence of novel, potentially virulent influenza strains by serving as __________ hosts that enable transmission between birds and humans.
Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) underwent a major genotype shift in 2004/2005 characterized by replacement of genotype __________ with genotype PCV2b.
Humans acquire fish-borne zoonotic trematode infections primarily by ingesting raw or insufficiently cooked fish harboring the __________ stage of zoonotic trematodes.
Swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV) is classified within the family Hepeviridae as species Orthohepevirus A in the genus __________.

Betanodavirus virions are non-enveloped, spherical particles with icosahedral symmetry and a diameter of about 25 nm, whose capsid is formed by 180 copies of a single protein with a molecular mass of __________ kDa.

Some emerging swine viruses with zoonotic potential include Nipah virus (NiV), Menangle virus, and swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV); among these, swine HEV has been definitively linked to human cases of acute hepatitis following consumption of __________ pork products.

Accurate discrimination of *Aeromonas dhakensis* from *Aeromonas hydrophila* in aquaculture disease investigations hinges on applying dependable __________ tools that enable reliable species identification and thereby support prompt diagnosis and assessment of zoonotic risk.

Oral vaccination in aquaculture often fails to elicit strong protective immunity because orally delivered antigens can be degraded in the harsh __________ environment and are further hindered by a highly tolerogenic gut milieu and suboptimal vaccine design.

In a U.S. swine production system, commercial swine can sustain high viral genetic diversity with comparatively limited zoonotic transmission due to high biosecurity, whereas exhibition swine can amplify human exposure but tend to lose viral diversity and host immunity when the show cohort is replaced at summer’s end; thus, exhibition swine function as __________ hosts in the ecological pathway enabling pandemic virus emergence.
Female feral swine can begin breeding at about __________ year(s) of age, a life-history trait that—along with low predation—contributes to rapid population expansion.

WFD outbreaks in shrimp pond farming have been associated with deteriorated water quality, with peak mortality rates reported when dissolved oxygen falls below __________ and alkalinity drops below 80 ppm.
The hypothalamic nucleus in chickens that produces vasopressin to regulate renal water reabsorption and thereby maintain water balance is the __________ nucleus.
Probiotic *Bacillus* can mitigate fish pathogens via multiple mechanisms; the mechanism that specifically involves enzymatic degradation of pathogen cell structures is the production of __________.

Probiotics can detoxify harmful compounds in feed through hydrolytic enzymes and by producing vitamins such as biotin and vitamin B12, while also inducing alterations in intestinal structure that enhance nutrient digestion and absorption, thereby increasing __________ and production scale.
In field diagnoses of bacterial gill disease (BGD), the long, thin rod-shaped bacteria observed on affected gills by light microscopy are typically presumed to be __________.

In adult chickens, the ________ jugular vein is preferred for faster collection of larger blood volumes, even though the jugular vein is highly mobile and prone to hematoma formation due to abundant subcutaneous space.

In the horse, the foetal testis is initially drawn to the inguinal ring but cannot traverse the inguinal canal at 100–120 days because rapid enlargement prevents passage; after reaching maximum size at 210–240 days, the testes undergo shrinkage until inguinal passage becomes possible at about __________ days of pregnancy.
Bird thymic stroma is derived from head mesenchymal cells migrating into the thymic primordium, whereas the epithelial-reticular meshwork within the thymus is specifically of __________ origin.
In dogs, infectious canine hepatitis is caused by Canine mastadenovirus A, a virus formerly designated as Canine adenovirus _____ (CAV-1).

Pancreas disease–causing Salmonid alphavirus (SAV) has a ~12 kb positive-sense RNA genome organized into two open reading frames in which the 5′ two-thirds encodes nsP1–4, whereas the 3′ end encodes four capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3 and 6K); therefore, the capsid glycoprotein ORF is located at the __________ end of the genome.

The canal neuromast system in guppies is surrounded by an osseous coat, whereas in the red-tail shark it is supported by a __________ coat, a difference interpreted as an adaptation to prevent canal-content compression under high bottom water pressures.

When cleaning eggs is unavoidable, the wash water should be approximately 20 °F (11 °C) warmer than the egg to prevent a vacuum-driven influx of contaminants through shell pores and to avoid damaging the proteinaceous layer that regulates shell permeability; this layer is the __________.

The omental bursa has a single entrance—the epiploic foramen—which is positioned caudomedial to the caudate lobe of the liver, dorsal to the caudal vena cava, and dorsomedial to the hepatic portal vein; in the dog, this foramen is slit-like and measures about __________ cm.

Paravertebral anaesthesia at T13, L1, and L2 effectively blocks GSA and GSE fibers in the localized body wall, yet autonomic function is maintained because the thoracolumbar sympathetic chain can compensate via a preganglionic-to-postganglionic neuron ratio of approximately __________.

The endocrine pancreas secretes insulin, glucagon, somatostatin, and pancreatic polypeptide from beta, alpha, delta, and gamma cells respectively, while the exocrine pancreas secretes an alkaline digestive juice whose pH is maintained primarily by __________ ions that neutralize acidic gastric contents in the duodenum.

In canine liver biopsies evaluated for copper-associated hepatopathy, special stains such as rhodanine or rubeanic acid are used to characterize copper distribution as periportal versus __________ and to help assess severity even when lobular architecture is distorted.

The superficial cervical lymph nodes receive afferent lymphatic drainage from the forelimb digits, metacarpus, carpus, forearm, and associated musculature, including the tendons of the __________ muscle (along with those of extensor digitorum communis/lateralis and extensor carpi ulnaris).

Subcutaneous mast cell tumours (MCTs) are best prognosticated using growth pattern, multinucleation, and mitotic count, with the strongest effect on clinical outcome attributed to __________ activity.

During glycogen mobilization, cleavage of \(\alpha\)-1,4 glycosidic bonds by glycogen phosphorylase uses inorganic phosphate to generate Glc-1-P, whereas resolution of \(\alpha\)-1,6 branch points by the debranching enzyme yields about 10% of glycogen degradation as free __________ that can be rapidly phosphorylated to Glc-6-P or released into blood by liver.

In grass carp, the absence of a true stomach is functionally compensated by an anterior intestinal dilatation termed the __________, whose wall is organized into tunica mucosa, tunica submucosa, tunica muscularis, and tunica SE.

Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency in dogs can produce protein intolerance and hyperammonemia with hepatoencephalopathy progressing to CNS depression, coma, and death if untreated; a standard management component aimed at controlling encephalopathy is instituting a low-__________ diet (often combined with oral antibiotics).

A clinician monitoring treatment response in a dermatophyte infection uses a Wood’s lamp and notes that hair shafts continue to fluoresce even after effective topical therapy, but only the __________ portion of each hair glows, allowing loss of fluorescence to be tracked as hairs grow out.
In marine teleosts such as percids, killifish, flounder, and sticklebacks, the nephron is shorter than in eels or salmonids because the __________ segment is absent.

For canine Malassezia dermatitis requiring an oral antifungal, the azole generally regarded as better tolerated overall than ketoconazole—despite possible gastrointestinal upset with both drugs—is __________.

Dysautonomia in dogs and cats produces consistent megaesophagus and regurgitation and is characterized pathologically by degenerative lesions in autonomic ganglia, intermediate gray columns of the spinal cord, and some __________ axons.

In equids, the term __________ is preferred over buphthalmos for an abnormally enlarged globe caused by chronically increased intraocular pressure secondary to glaucoma, because “buphthalmos” implies a cow-sized globe that is actually smaller than a horse globe.
South American camelids (SACs) are induced ovulators and lack an oestrus cycle, yet they exhibit a __________ wave cycle that ruminants do not have.

Surgical digit removal for septic pedal arthritis in small ruminants should be avoided when sepsis involves the proximal joints because otherwise persistent __________ will continue despite the procedure.
In commercial pig herds, helminth control can be readily achieved using in-feed __________ or fenbendazole administered at 6-monthly intervals.
A bacterial isolate carrying the **mef(A)** gene can resist macrolides by exporting the drug via efflux pumps powered by the __________.

During evaluation of a dog with suspected paw- or digit-origin non–weight-bearing lameness, palpation of the paw and digits should be performed while keeping adjacent proximal joints (carpal and elbow) in relatively __________ positions to reduce limb withdrawal and improve examination sensitivity.

To reduce seronegative subpopulations and improve PRRS control, incoming naïve replacement gilts should be exposed to the farm-specific resident __________ before entering a PRRSV-positive breeding herd.
In a dog with spontaneous pneumothorax affecting multiple lung lobes, the lung lobes most commonly involved are the __________ lobes.

In surgical management of intestinal obstruction in pigs where a stone is palpated within the small intestine, the obstruction may be resolved by removing it directly or by __________ it into the large intestine.

Virulent *Haemophilus parasuis* can resist phagocytosis in the lung through contributions from the bacterial capsule and two trimeric autotransporter family surface proteins named __________ and __________.
Bluetongue virus (BTV) diagnosis can be confirmed using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting viral __________, a method capable of detecting all 24 serotypes.
Nursery pigs infected with *Mycoplasma hyorhinis* that progress to systemic disease may develop pleuritis and a characteristic posture with the back curved upwards due specifically to __________.
In standing enucleation performed under heavy sedation with xylazine, a single very deep injection of 5 ml local anaesthetic placed behind the eye is intended primarily to block the __________ nerve.

In ovine infectious keratoconjunctivitis, the initial triad of clinical signs—preceding corneal opacity and potential ulceration—includes scleral inflammation, blepharospasm, and increased __________.
In poultry, the species-specific Salmonellae that are implicated in avian disease yet rarely cause human illness are S. pullorum and S. __________.

In canine geriatric-onset laryngeal paralysis–polyneuropathy (GOLPP), electromyographic and peripheral nerve conduction findings that are suggestive of an __________ disease help explain why older, large-breed dogs often also show esophageal dysfunction and decreased proprioceptive placing.
Cutaneous xanthomas are diagnosed histopathologically by identifying foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and prominent __________ distributed throughout the dermis.

Closed fracture reduction—defined as realigning bone segments without skin incision or bone exposure and typically followed by external fixation—is generally indicated for fresh lower-limb fractures consisting of only two fragments with minimal or no __________ of the bone segments.
In feline heartworm disease, echocardiographic diagnosis can be made by visualizing heartworms as two parallel __________ lines within the right ventricle or pulmonary artery.
A lizard with dysecdysis is at risk of toe necrosis when retained shed skin becomes constrictive around the __________, cutting off circulation.
When performing venipuncture in amphibians, the collection site should be cleansed with a 1:40 dilution of 2% __________ rather than alcohol to avoid irritating or desiccating the skin.

Salmonid alphavirus (SAV) is an enveloped spherical Togaviridae virus with a ~12 kb positive-sense ssRNA genome encoding eight proteins, of which the four capsid-associated glycoproteins are E1, E2, E3, and ________.

A urine sample that is reagent-pad positive for occult blood yet shows no intact erythrocytes on sediment exam can be screened by adding ammonium sulfate to 80% saturation; in this test, hemoglobin is completely precipitated while __________ largely remains in solution.
In commercial poultry, high-carbohydrate, high-energy diets can overstimulate hepatic de novo lipogenesis, contributing to the development of __________ in broilers.

A urine sample that remains reddish in the supernatant after settling or centrifugation (rather than clearing) most strongly indicates discoloration from dissolved pigments such as free hemoglobin or myoglobin, a finding termed __________ when due specifically to intravascular hemolysis.

De novo lipogenesis—the conversion of glucose into triglycerides (neutral lipids)—occurs primarily in the __________ of the chicken, and in laying hens this organ becomes a major source of egg triacylglycerols due to an estrogen-driven shift in hepatocytic lipoprotein production.
Plant-derived polysaccharides can be fermented by gut flora to generate __________, metabolites that can subsequently be utilized to alleviate intestinal dysfunction.

Ferret epizootic coronaviral enteritis—an alphacoronavirus characterized by up to 100% morbidity but <5% mortality—produces profuse green bile-stained diarrhoea with mucus that is commonly termed “__________ disease.”

Recombinant antibody libraries can exploit the fact that chicken immunoglobulin variable heavy (V_H) and variable light (V_L) chain sequences share identical __________ ends, enabling amplification with only two sets of PCR primers.
FOXO3 promotes skeletal muscle atrophy by upregulating muscle atrophy factors, including F-box protein 32 (FBXO32), which is also known as __________.

Recognition of viral pathogens by chicken pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) induces type I interferon expression, which then binds to interferon receptors and drives the induction of IFN-stimulated antiviral proteins that collectively establish an antiviral state in neighboring cells; among the characterized chicken type I IFN subtypes, the most recently discovered is chIFN-__________.

Hexavalent chromium induces noxious reactive oxygen species through the formation of transient __________ intermediates, which promote superoxide anion, hydroxyl radicals, and singlet oxygen generation.

Spring viraemia of carp virus (SVCV), an enveloped bullet-shaped vesiculovirus with a non-segmented negative-sense RNA genome encoding N, P, M, G, and L, is distinguished from novirhabdoviruses by the absence of the __________ gene normally located between the G and L genes.

Chicken nucleated erythrocytes have been leveraged as a biomarker of an animal’s long-term exposure to stress specifically because they retain a(n) __________ and can be readily isolated, enabling epigenomic profiling even in a highly repressive chromatin background.
Viperin can inhibit the trafficking of soluble virally encoded proteins during influenza infection by localising to the __________, where it disrupts lipid rafts.

Despite Newcastle disease virus (NDV) constituting a single serotype, it is genetically and antigenically diverse; within the two major genetic groups, class II viruses are divided into at least 18 genotypes labeled I–XVIII and exhibit greater genetic and virulence variability than class I viruses, so the class with higher variability is class ________.

Chicken primordial germ cells (PGCs) can be exploited for generating transgenic chickens because, after separating in the epiblast at Eyal-Giladi and Kochav stage X, they migrate to the germinal crescent and then enter the __________, enabling delivery to the genital ridges following circulation and permitting vascular injection of genetically modified PGCs into recipient eggs.
The in vivo assay that quantifies Newcastle disease virus virulence by inoculating virus into the brains of day-old chicks and yielding an index value is the __________.

Salmonella control in poultry has increasingly shifted away from antibiotic growth promoters due to concerns about resistance in human pathogens, making bacteriophages an alternative bio-control strategy; the direct therapeutic application of this approach to treat salmonellosis in poultry is called __________.

In the avian ZZ:ZW sex chromosome system, chicken females are ________ while chicken males are ________, and sex determination critically depends on dosage-sensitive expression of the Z-linked gene *Dmrt1*.
The study of many human-pathogenic *Cryptosporidium* species and genotypes remains poorly characterized primarily because only a few __________ are available for study.

In the chicken lysozyme locus, LPS stimulation of macrophages triggers transient synthesis of a(n) __________ RNA that evicts CTCF from the −2.4 kb silencer, thereby up-regulating lysozyme transcription.

Mycoplasma gallisepticum can induce chronic tracheal lesions in chickens by driving immune dysregulation characterized by excessive activation and recruitment of inflammatory infiltrates, yet the detailed molecular mechanism governing leukocyte recruitment and activation at infection sites remains __________.

Chicken body lice are described as obligate ectoparasites that complete their entire 2–3-week life cycle on the host chicken; therefore, they are best classified as __________ parasites rather than intermittent feeders.
The genome-wide phylogeny in which the Grey and Ceylon junglefowls form a sister pair implies their most recent common ancestor lived approximately __________ million years ago.

Borderline oxacillin-resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* (BORSA) is distinguished from MRSA by being cefoxitin-susceptible and lacking mecA/mecC while exhibiting oxacillin MICs of 1–8 µg/mL; this phenotype has been postulated to result from hyperproduction of __________.

The IFITM3 N-terminal domain contains a conserved tyrosine-based lysosomal targeting motif denoted Yxxφ; in this notation, the symbol φ specifies that the fourth position must be a(n) __________ residue.

TRAF family proteins share an N-terminal RING-finger domain plus five Zn-finger domains that mediate protein ubiquitylation and downstream signaling, while their C-terminal TRAF domain contains a coiled-coil TRAF-N subdomain and a conserved TRAF-C subdomain required for self-association and binding to regulators/effectors; the only member uniquely participating in both TNFR and TLR/IL-1R signaling pathways is __________.

Chicken IFITM1, IFITM2, and IFITM3 inhibit viral replication by blocking the membrane ________ step between virions and host cells, thereby restricting viruses such as influenza A virus and Ebola virus.

Chicken infectious anemia virus (CIAV), first discovered in Japan in 1979 from contaminated vaccines, can be transmitted both horizontally and vertically and induces anemia and immunosuppression in young chickens primarily through atrophy of bone marrow hematopoietic tissue and the lymphatic tissue known as the __________.
The red jungle fowl subspecies identified by mitochondrial DNA evidence as the primary ancestor of domestic chicken breeds in Southeast Asia is *Gallus gallus* __________.

An estimated __________ of dogs older than 8 years are affected by canine cognitive dysfunction (CCD), a condition marked by cognitive decline accompanied by cerebral degeneration and decreased cortical volume.

Because direct in-vivo measurement of spinal loading is not currently feasible, biomechanical cervical spine models are primarily used to evaluate the feasibility and potential side effects of surgical procedures and __________.

Intravenous administration of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in 7- to 8-month-old chickens was reported to cause a rapid reduction in peripheral blood monocytes and splenic macrophages, with these values returning to control levels within ________ post-injection.
Several dog breeds are considered strong candidates for hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) therapy because they are genetically predisposed to spontaneous diseases of __________ origin.

Dogs are recommended for routine evaluation in endemic areas of American trypanosomiasis because they are infected more frequently than humans under natural conditions, making them useful as __________ to estimate human infection risk.

In murine models of influenza A virus infection, high resistance to disease is strongly associated with strains that carry a functional __________ gene, whose product is a principal effector of the type I interferon–induced antiviral state.

The insulin-like growth factor receptor type 2 (IGF2R) is described as a tumor suppressor that sequesters IGF-II for internalization and degradation, and sequence alignment of its IGF-II binding region (Domains 11–FNII) across human, mouse, and dog shows ______% sequence identity, indicating high conservation.

KIT isoforms produced by alternative splicing of human *c-kit* at exon 9 differ by inclusion or deletion of a four–amino acid motif; the isoform that mainly induces loss of contact inhibition, anchorage-independent growth, and potential tumourigenicity is the one with deletion of __________.

In the context of leveraging serum tumor markers for malignancy management, the combined preoperative measurement of canine carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) with cancer antigen __________ has been reported to yield clinically useful information for the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer.

Despite being described as having little benefit for managing canine atopic dermatitis itself, __________ remain among the most frequently used medications to treat the pruritus associated with canine atopic dermatitis in dogs.

Canine scent detection studies for cancer have reported diagnostic performance that varies widely, with sensitivities spanning as low as ____% and as high as 99% when benchmarked against histopathology, a spread partly attributed to heterogeneous sample matrices and non-standardised training.
Methicillin-resistant *Staphylococcus pseudintermedius* (MRSP) has been reported worldwide and can cause sporadic infections in __________ who have contact with dogs.

Canine distemper virus (CDV), a Morbillivirus in the Paramyxoviridae family with a non-segmented negative-sense ssRNA genome, forms a tripartite replicative complex essential for both transcription and replication; this complex is composed specifically of the __________, phosphoprotein, and large RNA-dependent RNA polymerase proteins.
Canine norovirus (CNV) has four previously identified genotypes—GIV.2, GVI.1, GVI.2, and GVII—of which the genotype detected only in Hong Kong, China is ________.

Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is characterized histopathologically by extracellular matrix expansion rich in glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans, valvular interstitial cell alteration, and attenuation or loss of the collagen-laden __________ layer, changes that predispose to malformation of the mitral apparatus and mitral regurgitation.

Achieving complete functional regeneration after mammalian spinal cord injury requires not only generating new neurons and glia but also successful __________ of the correct targets to restore function.

The androgen receptor (AR) N-terminal transactivation domain contains polyglutamine (polyQ) repeats, and multiple studies indicate that AR transcriptional activity is inversely related to polyQ length; thus, a __________ polyQ tract is associated with increased transcriptional activity.

Antibiotic suppression of the obligate Wolbachia pipientis symbiont in *Dirofilaria immitis* rapidly inhibits embryogenesis and larval progression, implying that adult-worm survival and reproduction depend on the presence of __________ within the nematode’s tissues.

Canine parvovirus type 2 (CPV-2), a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus whose genome is 5323 nucleotides long with at least two major ORFs, can cause fatal gastroenteritis in young dogs and, in untreated pups, mortality may reach __________.

Rectal temperature measurement in canids is often selected as a minimally invasive proxy for core temperature, yet it may be impractical in aggressive animals or those with anal mucosal infection/rupture, motivating the use of non-contact __________ thermometers targeting sites such as the axilla, auricular canal, and ocular region.

PCR-based evidence supports provisionally assigning the etiologic agent of canine theileriosis to the genus __________, leading to its tentative designation as *Theileria annae* despite unresolved formal classification.

Sexually selected ornaments and weapons are expected to exhibit positive allometry in same-dimension comparisons (e.g., length–length), meaning the scaling exponent \(b\) in the power function typically satisfies \(b \, \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \, 1\).

A principal reason aged pet dogs are considered a strong spontaneous translational model for antioxidant intervention studies in neurodegenerative aging is that oxidative __________ accumulates in the canine brain during aging under human-like living conditions and diet.

The mucociliary escalator defends conducting airways by trapping inhaled particles in mucus from secretory cells and transporting this mucus anteriorly toward the pharynx via coordinated __________ movement.
Chronic otitis externa (COE) can become persistent when biofilm-producing bacteria—especially ________ and Pseudomonas—are involved, because successful eradication requires disruption of the biofilm.
MRSA lineages capable of infecting multiple animal species as well as humans are termed __________ genotypes (EHSG), reflecting their broadened host range beyond a single species.
Among the ten approved SGLT2 inhibitors spanning human and feline indications, the agent approved specifically for felines (and not for humans) is __________.

Histotripsy achieves mechanical fractionation of targeted prostate tissue by delivering high-amplitude ultrasound pulses shorter than 50 μs at a duty cycle below 1%, where alternating compression and rarefaction drive microbubbles to oscillate, coalesce, and collapse; this phenomenon is termed acoustic __________.

Dirofilaria immitis adults characteristically inhabit the ________ arteries and the right ventricle in dogs, a localization that underlies the development of potentially life-threatening cardiopulmonary disease.
Necrotic enteritis in chickens results from an abnormal increase of intestinal colonization by the Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming, rod-shaped bacterium __________.

CRISPR systems can inhibit the transfer of antimicrobial-resistance plasmids among Staphylococcus species by conferring __________ immunity, while the chronological record of past genetic invasions in a bacterial lineage can be reconstructed using CRISPR __________ sequences as molecular clocks.
Despite being labeled as noncoding, the ~850 bp long control region (LCR) of bovine papillomavirus contains both the viral __________ and binding sites for multiple transcription factors.

Adaptor proteins TRIF and MAVS activate TBK1, which phosphorylates interferon regulatory factor ___, a transcription factor indispensable for driving IFN-β production and whose phosphorylation promotes dimerization, nuclear translocation, and DNA binding.

In severe canine babesiosis caused by *Babesia rossi*, the host inflammatory response is characterized by a pro-inflammatory __________ storm, a systemic phenomenon that contributes to hemolysis, inflammation-driven multiple organ dysfunction, and parallels key features of human severe malaria.

Bovine babesiosis is characterized by intravascular haemolysis and vascular malfunction that can culminate in hypotensive shock, with hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria as predominant signs; the primary etiological agents in tropical and subtropical regions are *Babesia bovis* and *Babesia* __________.

Tuberculosis was identified by the World Health Organization as a major infectious disease for the first time in ________, following reports that included approximately 9.6 million new human cases and 1.5 million deaths in 2015.

Campylobacter fetus subsp. fetus can evade complement-mediated killing and opsonization-phagocytosis while also reducing detection by the host innate immune system primarily through expression of a protein surface layer called the __________.

The gold-standard diagnostic approach for prion diseases is the biochemical detection of the disease-associated prion protein isoform __________, which serves as a reliable marker due to its correlation with TSE infectivity and accumulation in the central nervous system.

In snakes, applying opaque tape to the outside of vivarium glass is a preventive measure for stomatitis because it reduces snout-rubbing injury by helping the snake to __________ the glass barrier and avoid repeated trauma.

Border disease virus (BDV), originally classified as its own species within the genus *Pestivirus* (family *Flaviviridae*), was proposed by the ICTV Flaviviridae Study Group to be renamed as __________.

Collagens, which constitute approximately 30% of the total protein pool in vertebrates and adopt a triple-helical supramolecular structure, provide high mechanical strength primarily by arranging into insoluble __________.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is caused by *Echinococcus granulosus* sensu lato, and in cattle the larval stage responsible for pathology is the __________ cyst.

Mammals show a dietary-linked divergence in mammary tumor susceptibility, with carnivore/omnivore taxa generally at higher risk and herbivores at lower risk; pigs, despite being cloven-hoofed and having mammary glands morphologically similar to humans, are argued to occupy an intermediate susceptibility partly because porcine epithelial cells can become neoplastic after oncogenic transformation and injection into __________ mammary glands.

The non-parasitic harvest mite *Neotrombicula autumnalis* is typically introduced via straw or hay bedding, and while the adult is not irritating, the irritating stage responsible for pruritus and self-trauma is the six-legged __________ stage.

Meningeal tuberculosis, the most lethal extrapulmonary presentation with an estimated >100,000 cases annually, is notable because central nervous system involvement is a factor for developing the very rare presentation of __________ tuberculosis.

Cows infected during early gestation with __________ BVDV may give birth to persistently infected (PI) calves that act as major herd-level reservoirs by continuously shedding virus from all mucosal surfaces.
BPV types BPV3, BPV4, BPV6, BPV9, BPV10, and BPV11 are taxonomically assigned to the genus __________ within the bovine papillomaviruses.

Fascioliasis, caused by the trematodes *Fasciola hepatica* and *Fasciola gigantica*, is classified by the WHO as a Neglected Tropical Disease and specifically belongs to the group of foodborne __________ infections.

Bovine babesiosis in cattle is most commonly caused by three Babesia species—Babesia bovis, Babesia bigemia, and Babesia __________—with the last being more common in parts of Europe and North Africa.

Estimates from Eastern China attribute up to __________ of human *Schistosoma japonicum* transmission to bovines, a contribution linked to intensive human–bovine environmental overlap in agriculture and exceptionally high bovine fecal output.
Mycobacterium bovis, an intracellular bacterium that causes bovine tuberculosis and can infect mammals ranging from cattle to humans, most commonly enters cattle via __________ or ingestion.

Pneumonia in young bovines is often precipitated by viral infections; two major contributing agents that either directly cause pneumonia or predispose animals to it are bovine respiratory syncytial virus (__________) and bovine parainfluenza virus-3 (BPI-3).
Human β-defensin 3 (hBD-3) exerts anti-inflammatory activity by targeting the TLR signaling pathways __________ and TRIF, thereby downregulating proinflammatory gene expression.

In South America, the bovine trypanosomiasis agent regarded as the most pathogenic and clinically important protozoan in cattle—capable of infecting buffaloes, capybaras, and wild ungulates, and transmitted mechanically by biting flies such as *Stomoxys calcitrans* and tabanids—is __________.
BPVs are assigned to genera using homology in the most conserved genomic sequence, the L1 open reading frame (ORF); this criterion places BPV-5 and BPV-8 in the genus __________.

Bovine tropical theileriosis caused by *Theileria annulata* can be controlled via a three-pronged approach that includes acaricide use and barn-wall interventions; one structural method specifically involves applying __________ to the outer and inner barn wall surfaces to destroy nymph lodgings.
Among papillomaviruses, the only types clearly documented to infect more than one host species are BPV1, BPV2, and BPV13, which belong to the genus __________.
Kisspeptin’s receptor, Kiss1r, is alternatively designated __________ in the literature describing its presence across diverse vertebrate taxa and one domestic carnivore (the dog).

Neospora caninum, an obligate intracellular apicomplexan whose tachyzoites replicate only within nucleated host cells and show an in vivo preference for infecting endothelium, has been effectively propagated in vitro at high proliferation rates using primary bovine __________ cells.

A non-synonymous substitution in the bovine PMEL signal peptide, denoted $PMELc.64G>A$ (NM_001080215.2), is causative for the Dilution locus associated with extreme coat color dilution in the __________ cattle breed.

The spatial pattern that FIV infection risk in Tsushima leopard cats is elevated where domestic cats are densely distributed was demonstrated using __________ data from a Geographical Information System.

Molecular detection methods have shown that in field studies up to 10% of FeLV antigen-negative cats are PCR-positive for provirus in peripheral blood, yet 96% of these provirus-positive/antigen-negative cats lack viral RNA in __________, a finding supporting the limited role of regressive infection in natural transmission.

Immunochromatography-based diagnostic kits identify feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) infection by detecting host antibodies against viral __________ proteins rather than detecting viral antigens directly.
Feline infectious peritonitis (FIP) is often definitively confirmed after death by identifying characteristic histopathological lesions of widespread __________.

In the BoHV-4 gene expression cascade, immediate early (IE) gene products expressed at 2–4 hours post-infection activate early (E) genes, and late (L) gene expression—encoding virion structural components—requires viral __________.
Reported prevalence estimates for feline thrombocytopenia span from 1.2% up to __________%, despite the rarity of primary immune-mediated thrombocytopenia in cats.
Feline chronic gingivostomatitis is a chronic inflammatory mucosal disease of domestic cats with an estimated prevalence ranging from __________ to __________.

Astrovirus ORF2, which encodes the capsid protein and is expressed from a subgenomic RNA, is preceded by a translational __________ between ORF1a and ORF1b that enables production of ORF1b-encoded RdRp.

In feline infectious peritonitis (FIP) with neurological involvement, multifocal surface-related inflammation (e.g., meningitis, choroid plexitis, ependymitis, periventriculitis) can increase CSF viscosity and precipitate obstructive __________ or hydromyelia.

A macroevolutionary pattern in which the apparent increase in mammalian body mass through the Cenozoic is attributed to increased variance without a corresponding shift in the minimum body sizes is termed a(n) __________ trend (Cope’s rule sensu lato).

Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) Vif mediates selective proteasomal degradation of feline APOBEC3 proteins via distinct motifs, where the N-terminal motifs 12LF13 and 18GG19 target FcaA3Z2 while residues M24, L25, and I27 target FcaA3Z3; the general A3-binding region identified by pulldown experiments spans residues ________ of FIV Vif and lies outside these specificity determinants.

Domestic cats are infected by two clinically important retroviruses—FIV and FeLV—whose prevalence varies with geography and indoor/outdoor status; a key behavioral risk factor shared by both infections is __________ behavior.

In feline assisted reproduction where intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is highly efficient and the sperm’s primary mission is to deliver intact DNA to the oocyte, sperm DNA damage is often attributed to __________ stress in the male reproductive tract, motivating supplementation of cryopreservation media with antioxidative agents.

Mesenchymal stem cells exert anti-inflammatory and tissue-protective effects largely via secretion of mediators including indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO), prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), hepatocyte growth factor (HGF), and tumor necrosis factor-stimulated gene/protein-6 (TSG-6); a proposed reason feline MSCs show limited benefit in chronic kidney disease is their poorer unstimulated production of __________.

Kittens infected with feline calicivirus (FCV) may show clinical improvement about 14–18 days post-infection, yet continued shedding via saliva and nasal secretions remains the principal driver of FCV transmission; this prolonged shedding most directly explains FCV’s high __________ in feline populations worldwide.
Feline coronavirus serotype II is thought to have arisen via recombination with canine coronavirus specifically in the viral __________ (S) protein.

Frequent encounters between domestic animals and wildlife can push endangered wild populations toward extinction because domestic animals often outnumber wildlife hosts of shared pathogens and therefore can maintain the __________ circulation of those pathogens.

In felids whose brachial plexus derives from ventral rami C6–T1, the muscle latissimus dorsi receives primary innervation by the n. thoracodorsalis and an additional axillary contribution from the n. __________ in both Panthera uncia and Felis catus.

In feline leukemia virus (FeLV) infection, the disease course characterized by an early immune response that fails to block the virus, leading to massive viral replication and spread (including infection of hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow) and resulting in persistent viremia is termed __________ infection.

Cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX-2), an inducible prostaglandin H-synthase family enzyme encoded by a fast-response gene, promotes malignant transformation in breast cancer by enhancing tumor cell survival via growth, invasion, angiogenesis, and the downregulation of tumor __________.

A lethal, systemic immune-mediated disease in cats that can arise as a complication of feline coronavirus infection is feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), which is caused by the __________ pathotype rather than the feline enteric coronavirus (FECoV) pathotype.
Pig kidneys are frequently selected for urologic experimental studies because their renal architecture exhibits close structural __________ of the human kidney.

Feline infectious peritonitis can arise when mutations in feline enteric coronavirus (FECV) drive a tropism shift away from intestinal enterocytes toward __________, enabling systemic dissemination and an immunoinflammatory syndrome.
Gammaherpesvirus reactivation is suspected to be promoted by co-infections or by compromise of __________ immunity, and in the latter circumstance can precipitate severe, potentially fatal disease.

Feline coronavirus can mutate from the enteric biotype (FECV) into FIP virus (FIPV), a variant that loses tropism for enterocytes and instead gains the capacity to replicate within __________, a shift that underlies its ability to induce feline infectious peritonitis.
In domestic cats predisposed to urolithiasis, increasing urinary pH above 6.4 preferentially favors precipitation of __________ uroliths rather than oxalate uroliths.

In Crandell-Rees Feline Kidney (CRFK) cells exposed to X-rays, the major DNA damage response pathway to double-strand breaks is characterized by ATM kinase–dependent phosphorylation of H2AX at __________.

Retinitis pigmentosa is genetically heterogeneous yet classically defined by primary degeneration of __________ photoreceptors followed by subsequent involvement of cones, producing early night blindness and progressive peripheral field loss before central vision is lost.

FeLV-B is generated when FeLV-A undergoes recombination with an endogenous FeLV element, specifically involving an endogenous retrovirus __________, yielding a tumorigenic subgroup that is generally not horizontally transmissible unless co-transmitted with FeLV-A.

In feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), the acute-phase protein alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (AGP) shows massive serum increases and is characteristically __________, a modification state that contrasts with the protective association of higher sialylation rates observed in humans.

Feline calicivirus (FCV) is regarded as having only one serotype, yet conventional vaccination often fails to prevent reinfection because the viral capsid protein evolves at approximately __________ substitutions per nucleotide per year.

The early vertebrate brain-segmentation terminology characterized the avian telencephalon as consisting solely of greatly enlarged __________, implying the absence of mammalian-equivalent neocortical structures required for complex cognition.

Cats infected with feline herpesvirus type 1 (FHV-1) can develop characteristic __________ corneal ulcers, distinguishing this pathogen’s ocular involvement from the oral ulcerations more typical of feline calicivirus infection.
Proteins and peptides constitute approximately 90–95% of the dry weight of snake venom and are typically distinguished by possessing either enzymatic activity and/or __________ properties.
Rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus 2 (RHDV2), a non-enveloped, icosahedral, single-stranded RNA virus in the family Caliciviridae, belongs to the genus __________.

Snake venom contains both enzymatic toxins (e.g., SVMPs, PLA₂, LAAO, serine proteases) and non-enzymatic components; among the latter, __________ are specifically named alongside three-finger toxins and protease inhibitors.

Feline calicivirus belongs to the Vesivirus genus and is characterized as a small, unenveloped, single-stranded __________ virus capable of causing both mild syndromes (pyrexia with oral ulceration) and, in virulent systemic disease outbreaks, high mortality.
Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) is caused by SFTS virus (SFTSV), a novel Dabie bandavirus classified within the family __________.

White-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) can substantially amplify adult blacklegged tick populations by serving as a major blood-meal source, yet they do not maintain Lyme disease transmission because they are not competent reservoirs for infection with __________.
Human polyomavirus 5 (HPyV-5), also called Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV), can cause a highly aggressive skin cancer after integrating into the cellular genome, a malignancy known as __________.

Facultative myiasis is subdivided into primary, secondary, and tertiary forms, where the defining criterion distinguishing primary from secondary/tertiary is the species’ ability to __________ the myiasis rather than merely superimpose on an existing infestation.
The major outer membrane protein found in the envelope and capsule of *Pasteurella multocida* that has been incorporated into fowl cholera vaccines due to its strong immunogenicity is __________.

In advanced atherosclerotic disease, the lesion phenotype with a relatively thin fibrous cap and a large lipid core is termed a(n) __________ lesion, which is predisposed to fibrous-cap rupture and superimposed thrombosis.
N-GPV has been detected by PCR from oral and cloacal swabs of ducks, supporting horizontal transmission via ________ and stool.

Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) is most closely recapitulated in humans by an animal model in which infection with Andes virus produces an HPS-like disease featuring a matched incubation period and the hallmark sudden onset of severe respiratory distress; this model uses the __________.
Duck hepatitis A virus has three serotypes (DHAV-1, DHAV-2, DHAV-3), and the serotype that has been the predominant viral type in China since 2013 with high morbidity and mortality is __________.

Despite contributing only about \(1\!-\!5\%\) of the synapses into the primary visual cortex, thalamic input can drive activity across the entire visual cortex only if thalamocortical synapses act __________.

Deletion of the gluconeogenic gene $PCK1$ specifically in adipose tissue is expected to inhibit __________, thereby reducing triglyceride deposition due to impaired de novo synthesis of glycerol-3-phosphate from non-glucose/non-glycerol precursors.

Mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) are __________-specific protein kinases that transduce extracellular stimuli into diverse cellular responses, and in mammals, 14 MAPK have been characterized into 7 groups.

In IFN-triggered JAK-STAT signaling, phosphorylated STAT proteins dissociate from receptor–JAK complexes, form homo- or heterodimers, translocate to the nucleus, and bind the cis-regulatory DNA motifs __________ and GAS to drive transcription of hundreds of ISGs.
Secondary amyloidosis featuring AA amyloid involves fibrils derived from the acute-phase reactant __________, which circulates in serum largely complexed with high-density lipoprotein.

The Lagovirus europaeus genogroup GI includes four genotypes (GI.1–GI.4), in which the pathogenic rabbit haemorrhagic disease viruses are GI.1 and GI.2, whereas the non-pathogenic rabbit caliciviruses (RCV) correspond to genotypes __________ and __________.
RANTES can inhibit viral infection not only via cellular receptor agonism (as described for HIV) but also via direct binding to viral __________ glycoproteins (as reported for human Herpes Virus).

Estrogens exert many reproductive effects by binding cognate estrogen receptors in poultry—primarily ESR1 (ERα) and ESR2 (ERβ)—which belong to the nuclear receptor superfamily and function as transcription factors by initiating gene transcription through __________ in target tissues.
Disruption of the m6A “writer” complex by knocking out __________ can produce an imbalance between proliferation and differentiation in stem cells, ultimately impairing stem cell function.

In poultry species, chickens and turkeys are the most susceptible to Newcastle disease virus (NDV), whereas __________ and geese are the least susceptible and are generally considered natural reservoirs or carriers despite resistance even to strains highly virulent for chickens.

Duck virus enteritis (DVE) is caused by duck enteritis virus (DEV), also termed Anatid herpesvirus-1, which is classified within the genus __________ of the family Herpesviridae (subfamily Alpha-herpesvirinae).

STING (also called TMEM173) serves as a scaffold in RNA virus infection by functioning downstream of RIG-I/MAVS and upstream of TBK1, and it can bind RIG-I (but not MDA5), MAVS, TBK1, and IκB kinase ε; therefore, knocking down STING would be expected to inhibit activation of __________ and increase viral replication.

DTMUV is a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus in the genus Flavivirus, and immunohistochemical detection of its antigen in the cytoplasm of cerebellar __________ cells supports the conclusion that duck neurons are primary targets of infection and replication.

Influenza A virus (IAV) strains adapted to replicate in birds preferentially bind glycoprotein-linked sialic acid receptors with an $\alpha$-2,3 linked galactose (SA $\alpha$-2,3-Gal), whereas human-adapted strains typically bind SA $\alpha$-2,6-Gal; in ducks, SA $\alpha$-2,6-Gal receptors are expressed only in the __________.

Ducks harbor all influenza A virus hemagglutinin and neuraminidase subtype combinations except __________ and H18N11, making the missing subtype the other explicitly noted exception to the otherwise complete HA/NA repertoire in this reservoir host.
In vertebrate skeletal muscle development, prenatal and very early postnatal muscle growth is driven primarily by an increasing number of muscle fibers, a process termed __________.

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are defined as RNA transcripts longer than __________ nucleotides that can regulate gene expression both in cis (neighboring genes) and in trans (across chromosomes) via mechanisms including transcription-factor titration, alternative splicing modulation, microRNA sponging, and recruitment of chromatin-modifying enzymes.

Pekin ducks exhibit tetrachromatic vision enabled by four cone cell species with peak absorptions at 415 nm, 455 nm, 508 nm, and 571 nm, and their color discrimination is further elevated because __________ in the retina filter incident light before it reaches the visual pigments, reducing spectral overlap among cones.

Avian divers face a propulsion trade-off because the medium used for underwater locomotion is approximately _____-fold denser than air, making large wings inefficient underwater while small wings are inefficient for flight.

TBK1 (729 amino acids) contains an N-terminal kinase domain (KD), a middle ubiquitin-like domain (ULD) that regulates KD activity, and a C-terminal coiled coil-containing domain (CC) whose function remains unknown; the KD and ULD are both essential for phosphorylating downstream IRF3 and NF-κB to trigger __________ production.

TLR3 transduces antiviral signals via adaptor proteins to activate transcription factors including IRF-3, IRF-7, and NF-κB, culminating in the induction of type I interferons and proinflammatory cytokines; in avian species, where TLR8 is non-functional and TLR9 is absent, RNA virus recognition relies primarily on TLR3 and __________.

The Parvoviridae subfamily Parvovirinae includes eight genera, and the genus with the broadest host spectrum—infecting birds, reptiles (snakes), and mammals (including humans and some primates)—is __________.

USP18, originally identified as a type I interferon–responsive gene rapidly upregulated by IFN-β via the JAK/STAT pathway, negatively regulates type I IFN signaling in a manner independent of its __________ activity.
During DNA-virus infection, RNA polymerase III can convert AT-rich dsDNA into dsRNA bearing a 5′-triphosphate that activates the RIG-I/MAVS axis to induce __________ production.
Follistatin (FST) overexpression can induce muscle hypertrophy largely by inhibiting the __________ signalling pathway, a key regulator of muscle development.
DTMUV is classified within the genus __________ of the family Flaviviridae and is characterized by a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
Duck viral hepatitis virus type 3 (DHV-3), one of the five etiologic agents of duck viral hepatitis, is taxonomically assigned to the genus __________ within the family Astroviridae.

Type I interferon signaling culminates in the formation of the ISGF3 transcriptional complex, which is composed of phosphorylated STAT1, phosphorylated STAT2, and the transcription factor ________ that enables binding to ISREs in interferon-stimulated gene promoters.
